'''Home Free''' is an American country [[a cappella]] group of five vocalists: Adam Bell-Bastien, Adam Chance, Rob Lundquist, Adam Rupp, and Tim Foust. Starting as a show group, they toured with approximately 200 shows a year across the United States.<ref>{{cite web | last=Gim | first=Esther | date=December 9, 2013 | title='The Sing-Off' Season 4 Premiere Recap: 10 Groups Hit All the Right Notes | url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/the-sing-off/the-sing-off-season-4-premiere-52089.aspx | access-date=January 5, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029013719/http://www.buddytv.com/articles/the-sing-off/the-sing-off-season-4-premiere-52089.aspx | archive-date=October 29, 2017 | url-status=dead }}</ref> The group won the [[The Sing-Off (season 4)|fourth season]] of ''[[The Sing-Off]]'' on [[NBC]] in 2013. They sang an arrangement of [[Hunter Hayes]]'s "[[I Want Crazy]]" as their final competitive song, earning the group $100,000 and a recording contract with [[Sony BMG|Sony]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Thompson |first=Erik |title=Minneapolis group Home Free wins NBC's The Sing-Off |url=http://blogs.citypages.com/gimmenoise/2013/12/minneapolis_group_home_free_wins_the_sing_off.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228044724/http://blogs.citypages.com/gimmenoise/2013/12/minneapolis_group_home_free_wins_the_sing_off.php |url-status=dead |archive-date=December 28, 2013 |access-date=December 27, 2013 |date=December 26, 2013 }}</ref>

The band released their first major label album, ''Crazy Life'', in February 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Ellen Kan|title=A capella country band releases stunning debut album|url=http://www.tjtoday.org/10144/entertainment/a-capella-country-band-releases-stunning-debut-album/|website=TJ Today Online|access-date=September 28, 2015|date=January 20, 2014|archive-date=September 29, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929171537/http://www.tjtoday.org/10144/entertainment/a-capella-country-band-releases-stunning-debut-album/|url-status=live}}</ref> Their latest album, ''Crazy(er) Life'', was released in March 2024.

== History ==
Home Free was originally formed in January 2001 by Chris Rupp, Adam Rupp and Matt Atwood<ref name=":0">{{Citation|title=The History of Home Free - Episode 1 (ft Adam, Chris and Matt)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ounzu9U8NNc|language=en|access-date=December 3, 2021|archive-date=December 3, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211203131711/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ounzu9U8NNc|url-status=live}}</ref> in [[Mankato, Minnesota|Mankato]], [[Minnesota]], when some of its members were still in their teens.<ref>{{cite web | last=Dyslin | first=Amanda | url=http://www.mankatofreepress.com/features/x1636698980/Local-a-cappella-group-competes-on-NBC-Sing-Off | title=Local a cappella group competes on NBC 'Sing-Off' | access-date=January 16, 2014 | date=December 8, 2013 | archive-date=January 18, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118113636/http://www.mankatofreepress.com/features/x1636698980/Local-a-cappella-group-competes-on-NBC-Sing-Off | url-status=live }}</ref> The five founding members were brothers Chris and Adam Rupp, Matt Atwood, Darren Scruggs, and Dan Lemke. They took their name from a boat owned by Atwood's grandfather who helped support the group financially in their early years.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.reddit.com/r/Music/comments/3lgh1w/ama_hi_were_country_vocal_band_home_free_ask_us/#cv6443d | title=R/Music - [AMA] Hi, We're country vocal band Home Free. Ask us anything! | date=September 18, 2015 | access-date=September 18, 2015 | archive-date=May 30, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220530222549/https://www.reddit.com/r/Music/comments/3lgh1w/ama_hi_were_country_vocal_band_home_free_ask_us/#cv6443d | url-status=live }}</ref> The group began as a hobby for the singers, but they gradually grew in experience and popularity. By 2007 they had enough of a following to pursue music full-time. During this period, the Rupp brothers and Atwood formed the core of the group, with Atwood singing lead tenor. Other members of the group came and went. Current member Rob Lundquist, another Minnesotan, joined in 2008.<ref name=vitug>{{cite web | last=Vitug | first=Joseph | url=http://josephvitug.wordpress.com/2013/12/29/the-sing-off-season-4-champions-home-free-country-tonix-part-1-evolution/ | title=Country-Tonix, Part 1, Evolution | date=December 29, 2013 | access-date=January 16, 2013 | archive-date=January 28, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140128031744/http://josephvitug.wordpress.com/2013/12/29/the-sing-off-season-4-champions-home-free-country-tonix-part-1-evolution/ | url-status=live }}</ref>

For much of the group's history they worked with many talented bass singers, but did not have a full-time committed bass voice. In 2007 Chris Foss sang with them. Elliott Robinson was added as bass in September 2008, and was replaced in June 2009 by Troy Horne. Later that year, Horne left to rejoin [[the House Jacks]]. To replace Horne they turned to Tim Foust, who first sang with them as a guest on their 2010 tour. A Texas native, Foust was then pursuing a career as a singer/songwriter of country music and had recently released a solo album, but was not ready to sign on full-time. Matthew Tuey sang with the group in the interim of 2011, until Foust joined them full-time in January 2012.<ref name=vitug />

In 2012, Austin Brown was working on a [[Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd.|Royal Caribbean]] cruise ship as a featured singer in their production shows. When Home Free joined the cruise as a guest performing group, they met and became close. Brown, who was born in [[Tifton, Georgia]], let Home Free know that he would be interested in joining the group if they ever had an opening. At the end of 2012 lead singer Matt Atwood and his wife, who had married the previous year, were expecting their first child. Finding the group's touring schedule incompatible with family life, and having an opportunity to take over his family's real estate business in Mankato, Atwood made the decision to retire from the group. Home Free then invited Brown to join as lead tenor. He sang his first show with the group in October 2012, and became full-time in January 2013.<ref name=ginger>{{cite AV media | title=T-Time with Ginger | medium=interview with Austin Brown | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Oz1vVztUGl0 | date=December 23, 2013 | access-date=January 16, 2014 | archive-date=January 14, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114124028/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Oz1vVztUGl0&gl=US&hl=en | url-status=live }}</ref>

The group, made up of Chris and Adam Rupp, Lundquist, Foust and Brown, competed in and won the fourth season of ''The Sing-Off'', recording their performances in September 2013.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news |last=Bream |first=Jon |date=March 16, 2014 |title=Harmonic convergence: Minnesota vocal group Home Free makes bid for national stardom |work=Minneapolis [[Star Tribune]] |url=https://www.startribune.com/minn-vocal-group-home-free-makes-bid-for-national-stardom/250244011/?refresh=true |access-date=November 6, 2022}}</ref> During that time, the group arranged for substitute performers to fulfill their previously-scheduled concert commitments.<ref name=":1" /> The series was televised in December 2013, and the group headlined the Sing-Off tour across 32 cities in 2014.<ref name=":1" />

On March 18, 2016, it was announced that, after sixteen years of performing with the group, co-founder Chris Rupp would be leaving to pursue a solo career. He would be replaced after May 8 by Adam Chance, formerly of [[Street Corner Symphony (group)|Street Corner Symphony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/homefreevocalband/posts/10153574817034007|access-date=March 18, 2016|title=Home Free|website=[[Facebook]]|archive-date=May 30, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220530222609/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fhomefreevocalband%2Fposts%2F10153574817034007|url-status=live}}</ref> On February 15, 2024, Home Free announced that Brown would leave the band later in the year, the first lineup change in eight years. This announcement also included the release date of their next album—''Crazy(er) Life'', featuring re-recordings of songs from ''Crazy Life''—to be their last album with Brown.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://homefreemusic.com/blogs/blog-1/important-news-update|access-date=February 17, 2024|title=Important News Update|website=homefreemusic.com}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=https://countryrebel.com/home-free-announces-departure-of-austin-brown/|publisher=Country Rebel|title=Austin Brown, lead singer for a cappella vocal group Home Free, has announced his exit from the group.|last=Smithson Aaron|first=Tiffany|date=February 15, 2024}}</ref> Brown was replaced by Adam Bell-Bastien, who had performed as a member of the group several years earlier, in June.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://homefreemusic.com/blogs/blog-1/adambastien |title=Home Free's Newest Member |author=Home Free |date=June 7, 2024 |accessdate=June 8, 2024 }}</ref>

== Reception ==
An update of Home Free's 2014 album ''Full of Cheer'' called ''Full Of (Even More) Cheer'' was released in November 2016 and debuted at number two on the Top Country Albums Chart with 13,000 sold - the band's best performance on the chart at the time.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7587829/garth-brooks-trisha-yearwood-celebrate-christmas-no-1-album |title=Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood Celebrate 'Christmas' at No. 1 on Top Country Albums Chart |date=November 22, 2016 |first=Jim |last=Asker |magazine=Billboard |access-date=December 17, 2016 |archive-date=August 14, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200814032228/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7587829/garth-brooks-trisha-yearwood-celebrate-christmas-no-1-album |url-status=live }}</ref>

The band has been actively posting videos to their Youtube channel since 2009. In May 2020, they announced that they had reached 1 million subscribers to their channel.<ref>{{YouTube|id=YCIWhMTKmdU|title="Thanks A Million." - Home Free}}</ref> Home Free was also an early adopter of [[Patreon]], where they crowdfund to raise money to produce their videos.<ref>{{YouTube|id=eii3zIlkRYI&t|title=Home Free - Now On Patreon!}}</ref>

The band cultivates a fan base, known as Home Fries.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Music |first=Home Free |title=Contact Us |url=https://homefreemusic.com/pages/contact-us?srsltid=AfmBOopuBiCP0lkf-5YFociQ9mMnbA5iqa5Iu-P_O9VhvRQHTNCJ5kgV |access-date=2024-09-15 |website=Home Free Music}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Release |first=Press |date=2019-06-14 |title=Home Free Leaves A Breadcrumb Trail In New Video For "Catch Me If You Can" |url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/home-free-leaves-a-breadcrumb-trail-in-new-video-for-catch-me-if-you-can/ |access-date=2024-09-15 |website=The Country Note |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":3" />

== Musical background and style ==
All five of Home Free's singers have formal musical training. Lundquist and the Rupp brothers all have bachelor's degrees in music. Adam Rupp's primary instrument is trumpet, but he also plays drums, keyboard, and bass guitar. Since joining, Foust and Brown have also become very active in writing and arranging.

In terms of musical roles, Home Free includes a lead tenor (Lundquist), a high tenor (Bell-Bastien), a [[baritone]] (Chance), a [[Bass (voice type)|bass]] (Foust), and a [[beatboxer]] (Rupp), who provides percussive sounds. Lundquist and Chance sing traditional tenor and baritone harmony, respectively, and Foust sings bass with the range of a [[basso profundo]]. Former high tenor Austin Brown is commonly known by his high notes, being compared with singers like [[Mitch Grassi]] from [[Pentatonix]], as he has a light-lyric tenor range. Foust is known for his extensive five-octave vocal range and his usage of the [[Death growl|growl technique]]. Occasionally, Foust and Chance switch roles, as Chance was the former bass of [[Street Corner Symphony (group)|Street Corner Symphony]]. All of the singers occasionally sing solos supported by the harmonies of the other singers.

Home Free's styling as a country group is relatively recent. Before Foust joined the group, Home Free was an all-purpose a cappella group, singing in a wide variety of styles, of which country was only a minor one. With the additions of Foust and Brown, the group moved more in the direction of country and found that audiences responded well to it. Home Free had auditioned three times for ''The Sing-Off'' (without Foust and Brown) and not been accepted. When auditioning for the [[The Sing-Off (season 4)|fourth season]], they made a conscious decision to style themselves as a country group. In an interview Brown said this identity is what grabbed the attention of ''The Sing-Off''’s casting director, who said, “You guys really fit something we don’t have.”<ref name=ginger />

==Collaborations==
Home Free has collaborated with many notable artists. In 2015, based on a recommendation from his children's elementary school music teacher, they were featured on [[Kenny Rogers]]'s final album ''[[Once Again It's Christmas]]'', performing "[[Children, Go Where I Send Thee]]" with Rogers.<ref name="Rogers">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6762595/kenny-rogers-home-free-children-go-where-send-thee-video-exclusive |title=Watch Kenny Rogers and Home Free Collaborate on Classic 'Children, Go Where I Send Thee': Exclusive |last=Dauphin |first=Chuck |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=November 16, 2015 |access-date=November 17, 2015 |archive-date=November 19, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119023008/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6762595/kenny-rogers-home-free-children-go-where-send-thee-video-exclusive |url-status=live }}</ref> Also in 2015, the [[Oak Ridge Boys]] collaborated with Home Free in a fully a capella version of their song "[[Elvira (song)|Elvira]]".<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=August 26, 2015 |title=Hear the Oak Ridge Boys and Home Free Reimagine 'Elvira' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] Magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/hear-the-oak-ridge-boys-and-home-free-reimagine-elvira-41633/ |access-date=October 3, 2022}}</ref>

[[Don McLean]] invited them to collaborate on a 50th anniversary recording of his 1971 hit "[[American Pie (song)|American Pie]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2021/1/29/don-mclean-releases-new-a-cappella-version-of-american-pie-f.html|title=Don McLean releases new a cappella version of "American Pie" featuring country vocal group Home Free|date=January 29, 2021|website=abcnewsradioonline.com|access-date=October 3, 2022|archive-date=January 31, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210131115500/http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2021/1/29/don-mclean-releases-new-a-cappella-version-of-american-pie-f.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Dowling |first=Marcus |title=Don McLean Joins Forces With Home Free For a New Cover of "American Pie" |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1829880/don-mclean-collaborates-home-free-new-cover-american-pie/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210203181109/http://www.cmt.com/news/1829880/don-mclean-collaborates-home-free-new-cover-american-pie/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 3, 2021 |website=CMT |access-date=February 28, 2021}}</ref> The music video for this performance went on to win three Telly awards in 2021.<ref>{{cite web |title=Don McLean + Home Free Win Three Telly Awards For Special Collaboration Of "American Pie" |url=http://www.enigmaonline.com/2021/08/03/don-mclean-home-free-win-three-telly-awards-for-special-collaboration-of-american-pie/ |website=Enigma Online |date=August 3, 2021 |access-date=October 23, 2021}}</ref>
Home Free has collaborated on several occasions with fellow a capella artist [[Peter Hollens]] on "[[19 You + Me]]" in 2014 and the hymn "[[Amazing Grace]]" in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web |last= Reuter |first= Annie | url= http://tasteofcountry.com/home-free-amazing-grace/ |title= Home Free Offers Stunning Rendition of 'Amazing Grace' [WATCH] |work= A Taste of Country |date= November 28, 2016 |access-date= April 7, 2018}}</ref> In 2020, during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] restrictions, Hollens and Home Free collaborated on a cover of the [[U2]] song "[[I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For]]", incorporating a choir made up of over 200 members of their respective [[Patreon]] patrons; each performer or family group recorded their audio and video remotely.<ref>{{YouTube|id=L6CE5IMX_7M|title="[[I Still Haven’t Found What I’m Looking For]]" (U2 Cover) Peter Hollens feat. Home Free}}</ref>

Also in 2020, Home Free collaborated with [[Lee Greenwood]] and the [[United_States_Air_Force_Band#The_Singing_Sergeants|Singing Sergeants]] of the United States Air Force Band in a recording of Greenwood's hit song "[[God Bless the U.S.A.]]".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Beviglia |first=Jim |date=July 2020 |title=Lee Greenwood Collaborates With Home Free And The US Air Force For Stirring New Version Of "God Bless The USA" |url=https://americansongwriter.com/god-bless-the-usa-lee-greenwood-song-premiere/ |website=American Songwriter}}</ref> The song was released on June 30, 2020, and reached #1 in digital song sales as of July 18, 2020.<ref>{{Cite magazine |date=July 18, 2020 |title=Digital Song Sales Chart |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/lee-greenwood/chart-history/hds/ |access-date=October 3, 2022}}</ref> Home Free created a song for the video game ''[[Skull and Bones (video game)|Skull and Bones]]'' (2024), which they performed at [[Summer Game Fest]] in June 2023.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/skull-and-bones-ubisoft-forward |title=Skull and Bones' Only Ubisoft Forward Showing Was an Admittedly catchy Musical Performance |last=Stedman |first=Alex |work=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=June 12, 2023 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pushsquare.com/news/2023/06/skull-and-bones-still-doesnt-have-a-release-date-but-heres-a-nice-sea-shanty |title=Skull and Bones Still Doesn't Have a Release Date, But Here's a Nice Sea Shanty |last=Tailby |first=Stephen |work=[[Push Square]] |date=June 13, 2023 }}</ref> Other notable collaborations include [[Billy Gilman]], Texas Hill ([[Casey James]], [[The Voice (American season 10)|Adam Wakefield]], and formerly [[Craig Wayne Boyd]]), [[Mark Wills]], [[Brooke Eden]], [[Travis Collins]], [[Amy Sheppard]], [[Rachel Wammack]], [[Cimorelli|Lisa Cimorelli]],  [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]], and [[Taylor Davis (violinist)|Taylor Davis]]. 

In April 2024, Don McLean again invited Home Free to collaborate with him on a new version of his song, "[[Vincent (Don McLean song)|Vincent]]".<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |date=April 30, 2024 |title=Home Free Teams Up With Don McLean for New Version of 'Vincent' |url=https://www.everythingnash.com/home-free-teams-up-with-don-mclean-for-new-version-of-vincent-watch/ |access-date=May 1, 2024 |website=Everything Nash}}</ref> It was also announced that Home Free would be featured on the title track of McLean's next album, ''American Boys'', released in May 2024.<ref name=":2" />

== Concert tours ==
Before their success on the Sing-Off, Home Free was touring at fairs and festivals across the US, as well as stints on cruise ships. Since then they have been part of the Sing-Off Tour, and headlined their own [[Crazy Life Tour]] (2014), [[Full of Cheer Tour]] (2014–15), Spring Tour (2015), Don't It Feel Good Tour (2015–16), [[A Country Christmas Tour]] (2016), [[Timeless World Tour]] (2017–18), and A Country Christmas Tour (2017). In January 2016 they embarked on their first tour outside North America with stops in Birmingham, UK; St. Andrews, Scotland; and London, UK (a planned stop in Dublin, Ireland was canceled due to weather).<ref>{{cite web |date=January 26, 2016 |title=Interview |url=http://www.music-news.com/review/UK/11636/Interview/Home-Free |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127090810/http://www.music-news.com/review/UK/11636/Interview/Home-Free |archive-date=January 27, 2016 |access-date=January 29, 2016 |website=Music-News}}</ref> In September 2016 they had their first concert in Central Europe at the "2nd European Country Festival" in Pertisau, Austria. In September 2019 they began their Dive Bar Saints World Tour, which was postponed due to the ongoing [[COVID-19 pandemic]]. In December 2019 they began their Dive Bar Saints Christmas Tour in the US.

On October 8, 2020, the band announced an [[Indiegogo]] campaign to fund a virtual holiday concert called "Warmest Winter" to coincide with the release of a new CD of the same name. The campaign met its initial funding goal in nine hours and stretch goals were added for further funding.<ref>{{cite tweet|number=1314380792232017920|user=HomeFreeGuys|title=CANNNOT BELIEVE IT. 9 hours. Y'all are amazing. We are OVERHWHELMED by the support. Working on some words for you all tonight. But for now we'll just say two: Thank You.|date=October 8, 2020}}</ref> The pre-filmed concert was streamed from December 2 to 5, 2020, and featured guest appearances by [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]] and [[The Oak Ridge Boys]], among others.<ref>{{Cite web |date=November 11, 2020 |title=How to Watch Home Free's 'Warmest Winter' Christmas Special |url=https://www.everythingnash.com/home-free-warmest-winter-christmas-special-how-to-watch/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220830235905/https://www.everythingnash.com/home-free-warmest-winter-christmas-special-how-to-watch/ |archive-date=August 30, 2022 |access-date=August 30, 2022 |website=Everything Nash}}</ref>
